Award.AwardTitle: A New Self-healing Mechanism and its Impact on Multiscale Biomechanics of Bone

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate the mechanistic basis of the nanoscale self-repair in bone and evaluate how it impacts the fracture of bone. These studies will add significantly to the understanding of complex biophysical self-healing mechanisms that are increasingly being applied to develop advanced materials. Understanding self-healing will also have a major impact on human health, by elucidating the impact osteoporosis has on bone repair, and may lead to enhanced therapeutic treatments for osteoporotic patients. An understanding of the inter- and intra-species matrix protein content will provide direct evidence of biomechanical and mineral variation between species, providing inferences related to bone evolution on a scale that has previously been under explored. The educational plan supported by this award focuses on developing new and interactive course content in Mechanobiology and Continuum Mechanics, two courses taught by the PIs at the undergraduate and graduate levels. The findings of this study will directly introduce interdisciplinary material to the courses mentioned above.

Studies conducted under this award will employ biochemical analyses and x-ray techniques to examine the association between non-collagenous bone proteins, osteocalcin and osteopontin, and the bone mineral phase within humans and across selected animal species. Nanomechanical testing and atomic force microscopy will be used to evaluate and monitor the roles of osteocalcin and osteopontin, and mineral in repairing nanoscale damage, under physiological conditions in vitro. Finally, multi-scale modeling approaches, incorporating macroscale fracture toughness and bone mineral data obtained from bones of multiple animals, will be used to develop a comprehensive understanding of how bone matrix self-healing at the nanoscale, impacts whole bone fracture resistance across various species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The bony skeleton has evolved a remarkable capacity to regenerate itself and restore normal mechanical function. Understanding the repair mechanisms is imperative to designing self-healing materials with superior fracture resistance properties. The unique interactions between collagenous and non-collagenous proteins (NCPs) and the mineral phase in bone matrix of various species determine their material properties and mechanical function. This project starts from the conjecture that, in addition to mineralization, the protein content also varies and significantly impacts nanoscale reparative mechanisms that help to maintain the mechanical integrity of the matrix. Currently, most smart materials need an external ‘trigger’, such as heat, mechanical stimulus, or light, to initiate the self-repair process. Unlike biological tissues, their repair is not self-initiated and self-driven. Furthermore, the repair process in these materials leaves behind residual damage and is unable to restore complete structural integrity. Bone on the other hand, is a complex biocomposite that dissipates large amounts of energy by virtue of its hierarchy and material organization.

 

Through the formation of microdamage, like diffuse damage, bone can self-repair without cellular involvement resulting in full recovery of original modulus over time, and a restoration of mechanical properties. Diffuse damage is associated with the denaturation of protein within the bone matrix under the action of applied stress. In this work we studied this process from both biochemical and biomechanical points of view aiming to identify the mechanistic underpinnings of self-healing in bone and evaluate how it impacts the nanomechanical properties of bone matrix and overall fracture of bone. To this end, we used experimental and computational approaches.

 

We investigated the structure-properties relation in bones from different species, ranging from bats to humans and whales, bones that have different degrees of mineralization and protein content. We conclude that both mineralization and protein content control the structure and hence the function and toughness of bone. Structure on all scales, from the nano to the millimeter scale, contributes to defining bone toughness. By a combination of experiments and modeling we established that nanoscale dilatation band formation mediated by non-collagenous protein denaturation is responsible to up to 20% of the total energy dissipated in the fracture process and repair/recovery following fracture. Hence, this non-cellular mechanism becomes an important contributor to function of bone. We performed studies of accelerated ageing by phosphorylation and glycation of human bones and observed that these processes reduce the effectiveness of energy dissipation and recovery mechanisms. This evidences a bio-mechano-chemical pathway.

 

The study led to a quantitative understanding of the contribution of this non-cellular bone self--healing mechanism to bone toughness, and offers a new perspective on age related bone fragility. It also indicates new avenues for the development of artificial biomimetic hard and tough engineering materials.
